user.biography:
Liv; Mama to Rory (23m) + 👶🏼 Bobby 👉🏼 @oliviasfoster
Early Childhood Educator & Nanny turned SAHM
PLAY Advocate 🌈 Art, Craft, Activities, Toys & Books

node.text: A Crafty LIVing’s Cotton Round Splatter Painting

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by A Crafty LIVing on August 11, 2021. May be an image of one or more people.

node.text:
Interrupting our usual Play posts to thank you all for the love on the unexpected arrival of our baby Boy, Bobby. 🌈👶🏼 I thought he deserved a spot in the Crafty LIVing feed to celebrate his arrival! ❤️

He was born via emergency c section at 32 weeks; but despite arriving 8 weeks early, he is a very healthy 2200g! I lost quite a bit of weight throughout the pregnancy, but clearly he was getting everything he needed! He will be spending quite a few weeks in the NICU while his lungs develop further. 
If you weren’t aware, I had placenta previa, so we were expecting an early delivery between 34-36 weeks - but 32 weeks was definitely quite a shock! 

Unfortunately everything happened too quickly so Dad missed the birth & isn’t allowed into the NICU to meet Bobby due to the pandemic; which also means Rory won’t be able to meet him until he’s home. 💔

Thank you again for the love we’ve received for our family & the stories shared of your premature babies. ❤️

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by A Crafty LIVing on August 10, 2021 tagging @acraftyliving. May be an image of 1 person, furniture and indoor.

node.text:
We’ve received so much love for our little Play table in the Playroom lately! 🌈 Rory has been using it so much since I’ve moved it out from the wall & into the centre of the room. 🥰
We made it using the same beech panels (bought from Bunnings) used to make the 2 shelves in the playroom, as well as our book bin. For the table, we used the same dimensions as the Kmart train table. We originally had the train table, however decided to make our own which is more sturdy & matches the rest of the furniture in the Playroom. 😍

Rory’s favourite thing to Play with on her table is her basket of tiny treasures! We have metal rimmed counters & magnetic wands, Grapat babies, acrylic cubes, folley bells, pom-poms, tongs, mini containers & matchboxes.
These are all things not typically marketed towards 18-24 month olds, however they are all of Rory‘s favourite “toys” & have been for the past few months. We use them only under strict supervised Play due to their tiny size & they are kept in view, but out of reach (on the top shelf). 

We recently made our Playroom more of a “yes” space, so anything in view & reach, she can Play with. For now, it works really well for us to have them in view for her to ask for them when she wants to Play. If it was to become an issue, I would move them out of sight & offer during times I am able to fully supervise. #acraftyliving_toddler

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by A Crafty LIVing on August 09, 2021 tagging @thecreativetoyshop. May be an image of flower and indoor.

node.text:
Sensory Play + Scissor practice with flowers. 💐✂️

If you’ve got a bunch of flowers in a vase or out in the garden that are starting to look a bit sad, how about giving them a new lease on life for Sensory Play! 😍 Our little set up included, bowls, jugs, whisk, water, magnifying glass, tongs & scissors, etc. 

Rory is using ‘Junior Grip’ scissors by @fabercastellaustralia - I introduced them to her at 22 months old. There’s no right or wrong age to introduce scissors, you can offer them whenever you feel comfortable. You know your little one best! 

These are the perfect first pair of scissors - the ‘blade’ is blunt so safe for use with supervision. They’re easy to hold & spring back open on their own, so all your little one needs to do is squeeze! ✊🏼

We have been using our Tuff Tray almost every day for Water Play outside. I’ve left it set up for her to come back to as she pleases. For now it’s just resting on a box as she really enjoys standing to Play and being able to move freely. Once I can source a metal frame, I’ll let you know! If you’re interested in getting a Tuff Tray, you can find them via the link in my bio under “Toys we Love” - just search ‘Tuff Tray’. 🖤

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by A Crafty LIVing on August 09, 2021 tagging @thecreativetoyshop. May be an image of flower and indoor.
Photo by A Crafty LIVing on August 09, 2021. May be an image of food, flower and indoor.
Photo shared by A Crafty LIVing on August 05, 2021 tagging @cleverpatch. May be an image of child.

node.text:
DIY Shape Roller! 🎨 If you’ve been following me since my Nanny days, you may remember this one. It’s so special to be able to recreate activities my Nanny kids loved with my own little girl. 🥰

This is an old favourite 2-in-1 activity. First they place their foam stickers onto a cardboard roll, then you roll it through paint or an ink pad (kinetic sand also works!) & then across a large sheet of paper for some fun shape printing! Depending on what stage your little one is at, you could trace the shapes onto the roll first for a shape matching activity. 

For Rory (23 months) I peeled off the corners of the sticker, as it was a little too challenging for her. We’re yet to roll it through paint but I’ll be sure to share when we do! This activity on its own (cardboard roll + stickers) is an easy little busy Bag for a Toddler. Stickers are always a hit in our house! 
Foam Stickers: @cleverpatch #acraftyliving_toddler

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by A Crafty LIVing on August 02, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, child and outdoors.

node.text:
Pool Noodle Hoops! ⭕️ Rory has still been very much enjoying the noodle tunnels we made a few weeks ago, but running & jumping through noodle hoops is the current favourite! We’ve been using them for both indoor & outdoor gross motor Play; perfect for all ages & so many ways to Play! 🙌🏼

I made the hoops with the same dowel I used to poke into the ground to create the tunnels. Super easy & inexpensive! 
I bought the noodles & dowel from @bunnings (hardware store in Aus) ✌🏼 #acraftyliving_toddler

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by A Crafty LIVing on August 02, 2021. May be an image of 1 person, child and outdoors.
Photo by A Crafty LIVing on August 02, 2021.
Photo shared by A Crafty LIVing on August 02, 2021 tagging @thecreativetoyshop. May be an image of 1 person and child.

node.text:
It’s easy to feel the pressure to pump out activities throughout the day for our little ones, especially for families in lockdown. 🙋🏽‍♀️

There are so many enriching learning experiences & opportunities through Play - the good ol’ simple, unplanned & ever evolving kind of Play. 
Our tuff tray has been such a great addition to both indoor & outdoor Play with some of the most basic household supplies. 
Yesterday it was just rocks, water & spoons, and today the Play expended throughout the day; with bits from her mud kitchen, plus foamy bubbles & a soap pump for hours of self directed Play as she came & went throughout the day. 

If you missed it in my stories, the body wash we use on Rory comes in a foaming pump bottle. I always save the empty ones to use for Play. They’re a great fine motor work out for little hands & fingers. We use the ecostore brand. For soapy Play, I use a small amount of bubble bath (also ecostore) & fill halfway with water. 
Our Tuff Tray is just resting on a big cardboard box until I get a stand for it. 

Tuff Tray Pre Orders are open for September delivery; there’s a link in my stories, or head to my bio under ‘toys we love’ & search ‘Tuff Tray’ to get yours! 😍 #acraftyliving_toddler

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by A Crafty LIVing on August 01, 2021 tagging @montmarteart, and @micador. May be an image of child.

node.text:
Outdoor Easel & Mud Kitchen ✨
Rory tested out her outdoor easel over the weekend! It’s been quite a while since we’ve done “big” painting so she was in painty-heaven! 🎨
Rory’s Dad made our mud kitchen using scrap pallets & we finally got around to getting some perspex to add to the other side to create an outdoor easel! It’s not quite finished yet - next we need to cut some circles into the shelf so the cups don’t fall or get in her way. 

Before she started painting, I showed Rory (23 months) the boundary (anywhere on the perspex) of where she was allowed to paint, before stepping back and letting her get creative! While painting in our house is a ‘sometimes activity’ for supervised art time only, she does have access to other art materials whenever she likes, so she is familiar with boundaries & consequences and was able to pick up the rules of this new environment quickly. In saying that, she is a regular Toddler and accidents do happen which is why we use washable paint! 🥳

When she was finished painting, we pressed some paper onto the paint to keep a print of her art. She then washed it down with a squeegee, sponge & the hose - double the playtime & half the effort needed from me. 🤣

We use @montmarteart Poster Paint & she’s using @micador paint brushes. 🎨💚 #acraftyliving_art #acraftyliving_mudkitchen

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by A Crafty LIVing on August 01, 2021 tagging @montmarteart, and @micador. May be an image of child.
Photo by A Crafty LIVing on August 01, 2021. May be an image of child and indoor.
Photo shared by A Crafty LIVing on July 16, 2021 tagging @urbanbabyshop. May be an image of child and indoor.

node.text:
Who would have thought pool noodles & pom poms could be so entertaining?! 🤷🏽‍♀️ 

Another simple Fine Motor activity to strengthen tiny finger muscles. 👌🏼 It also develops Bilateral Coordination, meaning she is using both sides of her body at the same time. 
Like any activity for Toddlers, these are not intended to keep her occupied for long periods of time, rather something she can come back to throughout the day for short bursts of Play. Rory (22 months), has been enjoying coming back to this over the past week. 
I just used a knife to slice the noodle into a few thick pieces. These are the perfect size for learning to thread too! #acraftyliving_toddler

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by A Crafty LIVing on July 14, 2021 tagging @spotlightstores. May be an image of 1 person, child and indoor.

node.text:
What are Rory’s favourite toys, &/or my favourite toy stores to shop. 🛍
These questions have come up a lot recently! 
And honestly, a lot of her favourite ‘toys’ aren’t found in a toy store, or the kids section of any shop, for that matter! Remember to check out dollar stores, op/thrift stores, crafting & hardware or general home goods stores for lots of supplies for DIY Play activities. 
You may have seen in my stories how much Rory (22 months) loves these tiny containers with anything that’ll fit inside. We swap between counters & pom poms, but the current favourite is folley bells! Both the bells & the containers I bought from @spotlightstores. But you can find similar in most dollar stores. 

Twisting the lids on & off is such a great fine motor work out for their little fingers. With anything tiny like this, of course supervision is a no-brainer! As for age recommendation, you know your little one best! Rory has been enjoying exploring twist lids from about 18-20 months old. Give it a go & let me know what your little ones think. Next we are going to start introducing some tongs. The best ones I’ve found for little fingers are ‘toast tongs’ - they’re wooden & can be found in dollar or grocery stores.

But if you are searching for a toy store with all the toys we love, you can find the link in my bio - “Toys we love” 🥰 #acraftyliving_toddler

node.text:
I shared in my stories how leaving Rory has been one of the hardest parts of my parenting journey so far, and I am not alone! ❤️
Your responses were so heartwarming, thank you for sharing your stories with me! We have been taking small steps over the past 6 months in preparation for baby Boys arrival. 💙
If you missed it; as a SAHM, I haven’t needed to leave Rory. Majority of the first year of her life was in lockdown. Rory’s Dad works long hours, 6 days a week. I crave a break, but when given the opportunity, I’d rather be with my little family. I cry to my partner on the regular that I don’t get a break, only to laugh about it later because we both know I’m not ready to leave her. 😅
My Mum, or ‘Ma’, will be looking after Rory when I go into hospital to give birth. Leaving her for an unknown length of time has me more anxious than the birth itself. I know she will be okay. I know how resilient children are. I know her needs will be met. But it is really hard!
For us, we have been spending as much time as we can with my Mum. We started by just having her come over & play with us, going out together in her car, & slowly over the weeks I have stepped back, staying out of sight for short periods.
She comes at different times of the day, so Rory can get used to her helping with different routines throughout the day. 
The next step for us is to leave them for the dinner/bath/bed routine. If your little one is going to be staying at someone else’s house, go over as often as you can, including for day naps & overnight stays. 

Whenever you leave, even for short periods, always say goodbye. Reiterate that you love them & you’ll be back soon. Having been a Nanny & a Mum, I’ve now been on both sides. Parents would sneak off to work whilst the little one was busy, however this would leave them confused & upset for longer when they try & find them. Whilst it’s hard for the parent to see them distressed, I’d always encourage them to say goodbye; we’d do a quick wave at the door, & then go and start the day. 

If you’ve made it this far, and any of this resonates with you, please comment below so other Mama’s know they are not alone. ❤️❤️❤️ #acraftyliving_newbaby

node.text:
Rory is loving her little baby role play corner in the Playroom. 👶🏼🍼 With not long until her baby Brother arrives, I’ve been collecting some more Role Play Toys for her & I thought I’d share some examples! 👇🏼
We know that children learn through Play, so Role Play is a great way to prepare your Toddler or Preschooler for a new sibling. Giving them the opportunity to explore experiences through Play, helping them feel comfortable & prepared for daily situations & life events in a safe way. 

Sharing a few examples of Role Play toys below to consider for a new big sibling - these toys can be played with independently, with visitors, older siblings, 1:1 time with a parent, as well as beside you whilst you feed the new baby. You may already have them, and if this is the case, you may consider packing them away, and returning them to your play space, week by week once the baby has arrived. 

Some new toys I have put away for Rory include; a new ‘life size’ baby doll, {with accessories; nappies, bottles, dummies, stroller, etc}. I am making her a Doctors Kit with real accessories - stethoscope, bandages, thermometer (button batteries removed), magnifying glass, small torch, tweezers, syringes, etc. This can be used for check ups for the baby, dolls, teddies, Mummy, Daddy & no doubt our very patient dog. 
She is also getting a cash register & tea set to accompany some of the play invitations I’ll be putting together for her. 
Keep in mind her 2nd Birthday is a few weeks before baby Boy is due so these will all be gifts from us & her extended family. 

Other role play toys your little ones may enjoy - a cleaning set, trolley, play kitchen, tool/gardening kit, picnic or dining set, occupational dress ups, etc. What would you add to this list? What Role Play toys do your little ones enjoy? #acraftyliving_toddler #acraftyliving_newbaby

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by A Crafty LIVing on July 10, 2021 tagging @thecreativetoyshop. May be an image of child and outdoors.

node.text:
Play is messy. ✋🏼🤚🏼 A little reminder, even for myself, that clothes can be washed, and showers can be had. 
Don’t get me wrong, I still find myself cringing. I’m still learning to not want to intervene. 😬

Let yourself sit back and let them explore without intervening with questions, comments or concerns, without telling them what to look at or what to say. 
Wonder what they wonder. Watch their eyes, their pace and their mind. It’s fascinating! ✨

We tested out our new tuff tray today, with compressed soil pellets - introducing Rory to a whole new world of Play… ✨ MUD ✨ 
Contained mess is what I can handle right now, so that’s what we did! 

Tuff Tray: @thecreativetoyshop #acraftyliving_toddler
